{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3309912,"name":"","username":"Orignl007","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-15T04:40:19.794Z","cooked":"

(If you dont want to read all of this at least skip the bottom)
Iâ€™m a little new to programming and others that Iâ€™ve asked donâ€™t know how to solve this issue, if it is one. We have MK4i swerve modules with one CANcoder on top and in all the programming examples that Iâ€™ve seen about swerve there are three encoders, 2 through bore and an aboslute on. I get how the absolute encoder is supposed to tell the code the position of the wheels regardless of the robot being on or not and applying the offset. and I get how you use it alongside with though bore. We had this with our old swerve but now wit the MK4iâ€™s we dont have through bore encoders and just 1 absolute. So am i supposed to only use the values on the absolute encoder?
(Skip to here)
Additionally, if Iâ€™m trying to call for this encoder, being the through bores or the absolute, how do I find their port/id. Because for the through bore, they are connected to the spark maxâ€™s, expectâ€¦ how do I find this port number from the spark maxâ€™s???

image771Ã—119 5.56 KB

I have some examples showing two number like that for te encoder ports, and then others with just one numberâ€¦ how do I refer to the encoder when plugged into the Spark Maxâ€¦ I have the spark max can id but I dont think they are the same thingâ€¦ help

If itâ€™s plugged into the spark max you can simply do

private CANSparkMax turningSparkMax;
private AbsoluteEncoder turningEncoder;

turningSparkMax = new CANSparkMax(turningCANId, MotorType.kBrushless);
turningEncoder = turningSparkMax.getAbsoluteEncoder(Type.kDutyCycle);

Hey, so we just finished trying to wire our things and we got power to the encoders and supposedly have a complete CAN daisy chain. We are using CAN coders so according to documentation you souldnt just connect to to the spark max directly. Your supposed to daisy chain it with the rest of the motor controllers, I saw no documentation on this (if you know any please slide) and all I saw was some wiring diagrams posted from other teams, showing that they connected they can coders straight to the Daisy train with the rest of the motor controllers

IMG_85951339Ã—1536 297 KB

we did this, and Iâ€™m not sure what the status lights were indicating on the encoders, but I also Donâ€™t remember the color, but they were red, then turn green for sometime and then the rest of the time we were trying to test I donâ€™t know what they were. Apart from that when we tried deploy code, and just using the code that was already on there, and the driver station, we were getting a system log saying that the CAN idâ€™s one through eight weâ€™re not being found/identified.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-02-20T23:56:38.100Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":31,"reads":82,"readers_count":81,"score":181.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":454823,"topic_slug":"absolute-encoder-ports-id-for-swerve-drive","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/3/733fa7c252cfdd348d215e5bd52c387fa841e965.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54288,"username":"GalexY","name":"Alexander Hamilton","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galexy/{size}/200203_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/absolute-encoder-ports-id-for-swerve-drive/454823/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3314077,"name":"Ross Hagglund","username":"diffy97124","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/a183cd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-21T00:52:15.107Z","cooked":"

I see that you define the drive and turning motor can ids, I donâ€™t see where you define the cancoder can ids (it is these ids that need to be fed into the swerve code as the absolute encoder). BTW as a best practice we avoid having anything with canid 0 as this is often the default of most devices so easy to have conflicts, and our swerve modules are all configured as:

 Module Location       Drive Motor Can ID     Azimuth Motor Can ID   Encoder Can ID
 Front Left                    1                   11                  21
 Front Right                   2                   12                  22
 Back Left                     3                   13                  23
 Back Right                    4                   14                  24

This allows us to easily identify problems based on the 1â€™s 10â€™s 20â€™s value and we preset all of these same values on our spare swerve modules so we can hot swap them at events if needed and then only have to change the offset value for the absolute encoder an we are back on the field. We have our modules wired such that we have a can wire in and can wire out to make the module swapping simple.

It sounds like you are using NEOs for your motors if you had the opportunity to use Falcon/Kraken then CTRE has an amazing tool for setup of an all CTRE swerve drivetrain.

How do I configure the CANcoder ID? How to I commect to it/set the CAN ID to be able to call to it in code?

Use CTREâ€™s Phoenix Tuner (Phoenix Tuner X - Official app in the Microsoft Store), my guess is that if you havenâ€™t set these ids then they are all currently 0 and conflict with your first motor can id.

Once they have valid can ids you will need to align the swerve modules and capture the offset from each cancoder to provide to your swerve code, so it will know how to align all the modules at startup (the whole purpose of the absolute encoder - I remember our first implementation where we had mag encoders and would have to manually align the modules before every matchâ€¦ )

For some reason, I thought you were using REV products. Wiring is a bit different over there. We still daisy chain. You could think of the CAN network (in the code side) as sending a message and knowing that there is a subscriber to that message in the network. There may be some differences from REV to CTRE, so I will slowly back into the nearby bushesâ€¦ Sorry I couldnâ€™t help!
